skill.name: Global Validation
skill.description: Implement comprehensive server-side validation with allowlists, type checking, input sanitization, and consistent error messages, while using client-side validation for user experience. Use this skill when validating user input, form data, API requests, implementing security checks, preventing injection attacks, checking data types/formats/ranges, or providing validation feedback. Apply when working with form validation, API endpoint validation, input sanitization, business rule enforcement, or any code that accepts and validates external data to ensure security, data integrity, and proper user feedback across all entry points.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation with validation guidance. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access beyond reading its own file. Purely informational content with no security risk.

content.value_statement: Improper input validation leads to security vulnerabilities and data corruption. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on implementing validation patterns including allowlists, type checking, and sanitization to protect your applications from injection attacks and ensure data integrity.
actual_capabilities: Implement server-side validation with allowlists and type checking
Sanitize user input to prevent injection attacks
Validate API request parameters and payloads
Create consistent validation error messages for users
Enforce business rules through validation logic
Apply client-side validation for immediate user feedback
limitations: Does not generate validation code automatically
Does not integrate with specific validation libraries
Provides guidance only, requires manual implementation

output: Email: Required, valid format, max 254 characters

best_practices: Always validate on the server side regardless of client-side validation
Use allowlists (positive validation) instead of blocklists for maximum security
Validate early and fail fast with clear, actionable error messages
anti_patterns: Relying only on client-side validation for security
Using blocklists instead of allowlists for input validation
Displaying raw database or system error messages to users

faq.question: Is client-side validation sufficient for security?
faq.answer: No. Client-side validation can be bypassed. Always implement server-side validation as the primary security control.

faq.question: What is the difference between allowlist and blocklist validation?
faq.answer: Allowlists validate against known good values. Blocklists try to block bad values. Allowlists are more secure.

faq.question: What types of validation should I implement?
faq.answer: Type checking, format validation, range limits, required fields, business rules, and sanitization for special characters.

faq.question: How should validation errors be presented to users?
faq.answer: Use clear, actionable messages that explain what went wrong and how to fix it. Avoid exposing internal details.

faq.question: Does this skill work with validation frameworks?
faq.answer: This skill provides general guidance. Implementation depends on your chosen framework like Pydantic, Zod, or Joi.

faq.question: How does this skill compare to type systems?
faq.answer: Type systems catch type errors. Validation goes further by checking business rules, formats, and security constraints.
